trans-unit.source: What is a Cloud Service Model and Package in Azure
trans-unit.target: What is a Cloud Service Model and Package in Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes the cloud service model (.csdef, .cscfg) and package (.cspkg) in Azure
trans-unit.target: Describes the cloud service model (.csdef, .cscfg) and package (.cspkg) in Azure

trans-unit.source: A cloud service is created from three components, the service definition (.csdef), the service config (.cscfg), and a service package (.cspkg).
trans-unit.target: A cloud service is created from three components, the service definition (.csdef), the service config (.cscfg), and a service package (.cspkg).

trans-unit.source: Both the ServiceDefinition.csdef and ServiceConfig.cscfg files are XML-based and describe the structure of the cloud service and how it's configured; collectively called the model.
trans-unit.target: Both the ServiceDefinition.csdef and ServiceConfig.cscfg files are XML-based and describe the structure of the cloud service and how it's configured; collectively called the model.

trans-unit.source: The ServicePackage.cspkg is a zip file that is generated from the ServiceDefinition.csdef and among other things, contains all of the required binary-based dependencies.
trans-unit.target: The ServicePackage.cspkg is a zip file that is generated from the ServiceDefinition.csdef and among other things, contains all of the required binary-based dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Azure creates a cloud service from both the ServicePackage.cspkg and the ServiceConfig.cscfg.
trans-unit.target: Azure creates a cloud service from both the ServicePackage.cspkg and the ServiceConfig.cscfg.

trans-unit.source: Once the cloud service is running in Azure, you can reconfigure it through the ServiceConfig.cscfg file, but you cannot alter the definition.
trans-unit.target: Once the cloud service is running in Azure, you can reconfigure it through the ServiceConfig.cscfg file, but you cannot alter the definition.

trans-unit.source: I want to know more about the <linkText>ServiceDefinition.csdef</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>ServiceConfig.cscfg</linkText><title></title> files.
trans-unit.target: I want to know more about the <linkText>ServiceDefinition.csdef</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>ServiceConfig.cscfg</linkText><title></title> files.

trans-unit.source: I already know about that, give me <linkText>some examples</linkText><title></title> on what I can configure.
trans-unit.target: I already know about that, give me <linkText>some examples</linkText><title></title> on what I can configure.

trans-unit.source: I want to create the <linkText>ServicePackage.cspkg</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: I want to create the <linkText>ServicePackage.cspkg</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: I am using Visual Studio and I want to...
trans-unit.target: I am using Visual Studio and I want to...

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new cloud service[vs_create]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Remote desktop into a cloud service instance[remotedesktop]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Remote desktop into a cloud service instance[remotedesktop]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The ServiceDefinition.csdef file specifies the settings that are used by Azure to configure a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The ServiceDefinition.csdef file specifies the settings that are used by Azure to configure a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Azure Service Definition Schema (.csdef File)</linkText><title></title> provides the allowable format for a service definition file.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Azure Service Definition Schema (.csdef File)</linkText><title></title> provides the allowable format for a service definition file.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the settings that can be defined for the Web and Worker roles:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the settings that can be defined for the Web and Worker roles:

trans-unit.source: You can refer to the <linkText>Service Definition Schema</linkText><title></title> for a better understanding of the XML schema used here, however, here is a quick explanation of some of the elements:
trans-unit.target: You can refer to the <linkText>Service Definition Schema</linkText><title></title> for a better understanding of the XML schema used here, however, here is a quick explanation of some of the elements:

trans-unit.source: Sites Contains the definitions for websites or web applications that are hosted in IIS7.
trans-unit.target: Sites Contains the definitions for websites or web applications that are hosted in IIS7.

trans-unit.source: InputEndpoints Contains the definitions for endpoints that are used to contact the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: InputEndpoints Contains the definitions for endpoints that are used to contact the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: InternalEndpoints Contains the definitions for endpoints that are used by role instances to communicate with each other.
trans-unit.target: InternalEndpoints Contains the definitions for endpoints that are used by role instances to communicate with each other.

trans-unit.source: ConfigurationSettings Contains the setting definitions for features of a specific role.
trans-unit.target: ConfigurationSettings Contains the setting definitions for features of a specific role.

trans-unit.source: Certificates Contains the definitions for certificates that are needed for a role.
trans-unit.target: Certificates Contains the definitions for certificates that are needed for a role.

trans-unit.source: The previous code example shows a certificate that is used for the configuration of Azure Connect.
trans-unit.target: The previous code example shows a certificate that is used for the configuration of Azure Connect.

trans-unit.source: LocalResources Contains the definitions for local storage resources.
trans-unit.target: LocalResources Contains the definitions for local storage resources.

trans-unit.source: A local storage resource is a reserved directory in the file system of the virtual machine in which an instance of a role is running.
trans-unit.target: A local storage resource is a reserved directory in the file system of the virtual machine in which an instance of a role is running.

trans-unit.source: Imports Contains the definitions for imported modules.
trans-unit.target: Imports Contains the definitions for imported modules.

trans-unit.source: The previous code example shows the modules for Remote Desktop Connection and Azure Connect.
trans-unit.target: The previous code example shows the modules for Remote Desktop Connection and Azure Connect.

trans-unit.source: Startup Contains tasks that are run when the role starts.
trans-unit.target: Startup Contains tasks that are run when the role starts.

trans-unit.source: The tasks are defined in a .cmd or executable file.
trans-unit.target: The tasks are defined in a .cmd or executable file.

trans-unit.source: The configuration of the settings for your cloud service is determined by the values in the ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file.
trans-unit.target: The configuration of the settings for your cloud service is determined by the values in the ServiceConfiguration.cscfg file.

trans-unit.source: You specify the number of instances that you want to deploy for each role in this file.
trans-unit.target: You specify the number of instances that you want to deploy for each role in this file.

trans-unit.source: The values for the configuration settings that you defined in the service definition file are added to the service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The values for the configuration settings that you defined in the service definition file are added to the service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The thumbprints for any management certificates that are associated with the cloud service are also added to the file.
trans-unit.target: The thumbprints for any management certificates that are associated with the cloud service are also added to the file.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Azure Service Configuration Schema (.cscfg File)</linkText><title></title> provides the allowable format for a service configuration file.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Azure Service Configuration Schema (.cscfg File)</linkText><title></title> provides the allowable format for a service configuration file.

trans-unit.source: The service configuration file is not packaged with the application, but is uploaded to Azure as a separate file and is used to configure the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The service configuration file is not packaged with the application, but is uploaded to Azure as a separate file and is used to configure the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: You can upload a new service configuration file without redeploying your cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You can upload a new service configuration file without redeploying your cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The configuration values for the cloud service can be changed while the cloud service is running.
trans-unit.target: The configuration values for the cloud service can be changed while the cloud service is running.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows the configuration settings that can be defined for the Web and Worker roles:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows the configuration settings that can be defined for the Web and Worker roles:

trans-unit.source: You can refer to the <linkText>Service Configuration Schema</linkText><title></title> for better understanding the XML schema used here, however, here is a quick explanation of the elements:
trans-unit.target: You can refer to the <linkText>Service Configuration Schema</linkText><title></title> for better understanding the XML schema used here, however, here is a quick explanation of the elements:

trans-unit.source: Instances Configures the number of running instances for the role.
trans-unit.target: Instances Configures the number of running instances for the role.

trans-unit.source: To prevent your cloud service from potentially becoming unavailable during upgrades, it is recommend that you deploy more than one instance of your web-facing roles.
trans-unit.target: To prevent your cloud service from potentially becoming unavailable during upgrades, it is recommend that you deploy more than one instance of your web-facing roles.

trans-unit.source: By doing this, you are adhering to the guidelines in the <linkText>Azure Compute Service Level Agreement (SLA)</linkText><title></title>, which guarantees 99.95% external connectivity for Internet-facing roles when two or more role instances are deployed for a service.
trans-unit.target: By doing this, you are adhering to the guidelines in the <linkText>Azure Compute Service Level Agreement (SLA)</linkText><title></title>, which guarantees 99.95% external connectivity for Internet-facing roles when two or more role instances are deployed for a service.

trans-unit.source: ConfigurationSettings Configures the settings for the running instances for a role. The name of the elements must match the setting definitions in the service definition file.
trans-unit.target: ConfigurationSettings Configures the settings for the running instances for a role. The name of the elements must match the setting definitions in the service definition file.

trans-unit.source: Certificates Configures the certificates that are used by the service.
trans-unit.target: Certificates Configures the certificates that are used by the service.

trans-unit.source: The previous code example shows how to define the certificate for the RemoteAccess module.
trans-unit.target: The previous code example shows how to define the certificate for the RemoteAccess module.

trans-unit.source: The value of the thumbprint attribute must be set to the thumbprint of the certificate to use.
trans-unit.target: The value of the thumbprint attribute must be set to the thumbprint of the certificate to use.

trans-unit.source: The thumbprint for the certificate can be added to the configuration file by using a text editor, or the value can be added on the Certificates tab of the Properties page of the role in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The thumbprint for the certificate can be added to the configuration file by using a text editor, or the value can be added on the Certificates tab of the Properties page of the role in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Azure allows only one entry point to a web role.
trans-unit.target: Azure allows only one entry point to a web role.

trans-unit.source: This means that all traffic occurs through one IP address.
trans-unit.target: This means that all traffic occurs through one IP address.

trans-unit.source: You can configure your websites to share a port by configuring the host header to direct the request to the correct location.
trans-unit.target: You can configure your websites to share a port by configuring the host header to direct the request to the correct location.

trans-unit.source: You can also configure your applications to listen to well-known ports on the IP address.
trans-unit.target: You can also configure your applications to listen to well-known ports on the IP address.

trans-unit.source: The following sample shows the configuration for a web role with a website and web application.
trans-unit.target: The following sample shows the configuration for a web role with a website and web application.

trans-unit.source: The website is configured as the default entry location on port 80, and the web applications are configured to receive requests from an alternate host header that is called “mail.mysite.cloudapp.net”.
trans-unit.target: The website is configured as the default entry location on port 80, and the web applications are configured to receive requests from an alternate host header that is called “mail.mysite.cloudapp.net”.

trans-unit.source: You can update the configuration of your cloud service while it is running in Azure, without taking the service offline.
trans-unit.target: You can update the configuration of your cloud service while it is running in Azure, without taking the service offline.

trans-unit.source: To change configuration information, you can either upload a new configuration file, or edit the configuration file in place and apply it to your running service.
trans-unit.target: To change configuration information, you can either upload a new configuration file, or edit the configuration file in place and apply it to your running service.

trans-unit.source: The following changes can be made to the configuration of a service:
trans-unit.target: The following changes can be made to the configuration of a service:

trans-unit.source: Changing the values of configuration settings When a configuration setting changes, a role instance can choose to apply the change while the instance is online, or to recycle the instance gracefully and apply the change while the instance is offline.
trans-unit.target: Changing the values of configuration settings When a configuration setting changes, a role instance can choose to apply the change while the instance is online, or to recycle the instance gracefully and apply the change while the instance is offline.

trans-unit.source: Changing the service topology of role instances Topology changes do not affect running instances, except where an instance is being removed.
trans-unit.target: Changing the service topology of role instances Topology changes do not affect running instances, except where an instance is being removed.

trans-unit.source: All remaining instances generally do not need to be recycled; however, you can choose to recycle role instances in response to a topology change.
trans-unit.target: All remaining instances generally do not need to be recycled; however, you can choose to recycle role instances in response to a topology change.

trans-unit.source: Changing the certificate thumbprint You can only update a certificate when a role instance is offline.
trans-unit.target: Changing the certificate thumbprint You can only update a certificate when a role instance is offline.

trans-unit.source: If a certificate is added, deleted, or changed while a role instance is online, Azure gracefully takes the instance offline to update the certificate and bring it back online after the change is complete.
trans-unit.target: If a certificate is added, deleted, or changed while a role instance is online, Azure gracefully takes the instance offline to update the certificate and bring it back online after the change is complete.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Azure Runtime Library</linkText><title></title> includes the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime</linkText><title></title> namespace, which provides classes for interacting with the Azure environment from code running in an instance of a role.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Azure Runtime Library</linkText><title></title> includes the <linkText>Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime</linkText><title></title> namespace, which provides classes for interacting with the Azure environment from code running in an instance of a role.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>RoleEnvironment</linkText><title></title> class defines the following events that are raised before and after a configuration change:
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>RoleEnvironment</linkText><title></title> class defines the following events that are raised before and after a configuration change:

trans-unit.source: [Changing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.serviceruntime.roleenvironment.changing.aspx) event This occurs before the configuration change is applied to a specified instance of a role giving you a chance to take down the role instances if required.
trans-unit.target: [Changing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.serviceruntime.roleenvironment.changing.aspx) event This occurs before the configuration change is applied to a specified instance of a role giving you a chance to take down the role instances if required.

trans-unit.source: [Changed](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.serviceruntime.roleenvironment.changed.aspx) event Occurs after the configuration change is applied to a specified instance of a role.
trans-unit.target: [Changed](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.serviceruntime.roleenvironment.changed.aspx) event Occurs after the configuration change is applied to a specified instance of a role.

trans-unit.source: Because certificate changes always take the instances of a role offline, they do not raise the RoleEnvironment.Changing or RoleEnvironment.Changed events.
trans-unit.target: Because certificate changes always take the instances of a role offline, they do not raise the RoleEnvironment.Changing or RoleEnvironment.Changed events.

trans-unit.source: To deploy an application as a cloud service in Azure, you must first package the application in the appropriate format.
trans-unit.target: To deploy an application as a cloud service in Azure, you must first package the application in the appropriate format.

trans-unit.source: You can use the CSPack command-line tool (installed with the Azure SDK) to create the package file as an alternative to Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: You can use the CSPack command-line tool (installed with the Azure SDK) to create the package file as an alternative to Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: CSPack uses the contents of the service definition file and service configuration file to define the contents of the package.
trans-unit.target: CSPack uses the contents of the service definition file and service configuration file to define the contents of the package.

trans-unit.source: CSPack generates an application package file (.cspkg) that you can upload to Azure by using the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: CSPack generates an application package file (.cspkg) that you can upload to Azure by using the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: By default, the package is named [ServiceDefinitionFileName].cspkg, but you can specify a different name by using the /out option of CSPack.
trans-unit.target: By default, the package is named [ServiceDefinitionFileName].cspkg, but you can specify a different name by using the /out option of CSPack.

trans-unit.source: SDK Version
trans-unit.target: SDK Version

trans-unit.source: Path
trans-unit.target: Path

trans-unit.source: C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft SDKs\\Azure\\.NET SDK\\\[sdk-version\]\\bin\\
trans-unit.target: C:\\Program Files\\Microsoft SDKs\\Azure\\.NET SDK\\\[sdk-version\]\\bin\\

trans-unit.source: C:\\Program Files\\Azure SDK\\\[sdk-version\]\\bin\\
trans-unit.target: C:\\Program Files\\Azure SDK\\\[sdk-version\]\\bin\\

trans-unit.source: CSPack.exe (on windows) is available by running the Microsoft Azure Command Prompt shortcut that is installed with the SDK.
trans-unit.target: CSPack.exe (on windows) is available by running the Microsoft Azure Command Prompt shortcut that is installed with the SDK.

trans-unit.source: Run the CSPack.exe program by itself to see documentation about all of the possible switches and commands.
trans-unit.target: Run the CSPack.exe program by itself to see documentation about all of the possible switches and commands.

trans-unit.source: Run your cloud service locally in the Microsoft Azure Compute Emulator, use the /copyonly option This option copies the binary files for the application to a directory layout from which they can be run in the compute emulator.
trans-unit.target: Run your cloud service locally in the Microsoft Azure Compute Emulator, use the /copyonly option This option copies the binary files for the application to a directory layout from which they can be run in the compute emulator.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates an application package that contains the information for a web role.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates an application package that contains the information for a web role.

trans-unit.source: The command specifies the service definition file to use, the directory where binary files can be found, and the name of the package file.
trans-unit.target: The command specifies the service definition file to use, the directory where binary files can be found, and the name of the package file.

trans-unit.source: If the application contains both a web role and a worker role, the following command is used:
trans-unit.target: If the application contains both a web role and a worker role, the following command is used:

trans-unit.source: Where the variables are defined as follows:
trans-unit.target: Where the variables are defined as follows:

trans-unit.source: Variable
trans-unit.target: Variable

trans-unit.source: Value
trans-unit.target: Value

trans-unit.source: \[DirectoryName\]
trans-unit.target: \[DirectoryName\]

trans-unit.source: The subdirectory under the root project directory that contains the .csdef file of the Azure project.
trans-unit.target: The subdirectory under the root project directory that contains the .csdef file of the Azure project.

trans-unit.source: \[ServiceDefinition\]
trans-unit.target: \[ServiceDefinition\]

trans-unit.source: The name of the service definition file.
trans-unit.target: The name of the service definition file.

trans-unit.source: By default, this file is named ServiceDefinition.csdef.
trans-unit.target: By default, this file is named ServiceDefinition.csdef.

trans-unit.source: \[OutputFileName\]
trans-unit.target: \[OutputFileName\]

trans-unit.source: The name for the generated package file.
trans-unit.target: The name for the generated package file.

trans-unit.source: Typically, this is set to the name of the application.
trans-unit.target: Typically, this is set to the name of the application.

trans-unit.source: If no file name is specified, the application package is created as \[ApplicationName\].cspkg.
trans-unit.target: If no file name is specified, the application package is created as \[ApplicationName\].cspkg.

trans-unit.source: \[RoleName\]
trans-unit.target: \[RoleName\]

trans-unit.source: The name of the role as defined in the service definition file.
trans-unit.target: The name of the role as defined in the service definition file.

trans-unit.source: \[RoleBinariesDirectory]
trans-unit.target: \[RoleBinariesDirectory]

trans-unit.source: The location of the binary files for the role.
trans-unit.target: The location of the binary files for the role.

trans-unit.source: \[VirtualPath\]
trans-unit.target: \[VirtualPath\]

trans-unit.source: The physical directories for each virtual path defined in the Sites section of the service definition.
trans-unit.target: The physical directories for each virtual path defined in the Sites section of the service definition.

trans-unit.source: \[PhysicalPath\]
trans-unit.target: \[PhysicalPath\]

trans-unit.source: The physical directories of the contents for each virtual path defined in the site node of the service definition.
trans-unit.target: The physical directories of the contents for each virtual path defined in the site node of the service definition.

trans-unit.source: \[RoleAssemblyName\]
trans-unit.target: \[RoleAssemblyName\]

trans-unit.source: The name of the binary file for the role.
trans-unit.target: The name of the binary file for the role.
